Eddie_Noack:
{{short description|American singer-songwriter}}

'''De Armand Alexander''' "'''Eddie'''" '''Noack, Jr.''' (April 29, 1930 – February 5, 1978),<ref name="AMG"/> was an American [[country music|country and western]] singer, songwriter and music industry executive. He is best known for his 1968 recording of the controversial [[murder ballad]], "Psycho", written by [[Leon Payne]], produced by John Capps and issued on the K-ark Records label.

==Early life and career==
Noack was born in [[Houston]], [[Texas]], United States,<ref name="AMG"/> and attended [[Baylor University]], where he earned a bachelor of arts degree in English and journalism.<ref name="AMG">{{cite web|title=Eddie Noack|url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/eddie-noack-p19605/biography|website=[[AllMusic]]|access-date=January 23, 2012}}</ref> Noack decided on a career in music after winning a talent contest in 1947.<ref name="AMG"/> A [[honky tonk]] singer influenced by [[Hank Williams, Sr.|Hank Williams]], he appeared frequently on radio and was signed by [[Gold Star Records]] in 1949.<ref name="AMG"/> That same year, Gold Star released his song "Gentlemen Prefer Blondes", which was not a cover of the eponymous song from the [[Gentlemen Prefer Blondes (musical)|1949 musical]], but a parody of it.<ref name="AMG"/> He also recorded the single "Have Blues Will Travel" / "The Price of Love" for Gold Star in 1959, but recorded for many labels during the decade of the 1950s.

He began recording for [[Four Star Records|Four Star]] in 1951 as part of [[:de:R.D. Hendon and his Western Jamboree Cowboys|R.D. Hendon and His Western Jamboree Cowboys]], a band specializing in the honky tonk, country swing, and country boogie styles, and later [[rockabilly]].<ref name="Love">{{cite web|title=Love 'im, Hate 'im... It's Eddie Noack|url=http://westex-countrywestern.blogspot.com/2009/06/love-im-hate-im-its-eddie-noack.html|website=Westex-countrywestern.blogspot.com|access-date=January 26, 2012}}</ref> (The band later recorded Noack's song "We Smiled" as a B-side in 1956 for [[Starday Records|Starday]].)<ref>{{cite web|author=|title=RD Hendon And His Western Jamboree Cowboys - We Smiled (1956)|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_SdxbgK8Ack|publisher=[[YouTube]]|access-date=January 26, 2012}}</ref> "Too Hot To Handle", his own composition, was leased by Four Star to TNT Records, establishing his reputation as a songwriter. In 1953, he was signed by Starday, which was owned by record producer [[Pappy Daily]], with whom he would work for the bulk of his professional career.<ref>{{cite web|title=EDDIE NOACK|url=http://www.rockabilly.nl/references/messages/eddie_noack.htm|publisher=Rockabilly.nl|access-date=January 26, 2012}}</ref>

Noack was drafted in 1954 and spent two years in the Army.<ref name="Love"/> When Noack came home, he adopted a female [[Dachshund|sausage dog]], named Biscuit. Back in the music business, he flourished as a songwriter at Starday, with [[Hank Snow]]'s cover of his song "These Hands" reaching No. 5 on the country chart in 1956.<ref name="AMG"/> When Pappy Daily founded [[D Records]] in 1958, he signed Noack, and his recording of his own composition "Have Blues Will Travel" reached No. 14 on the country chart.<ref name="AMG"/> Under the name Tommy Wood, Noack recorded [[rockabilly]] music.<ref name="LarkinCountry">{{cite book|title=[[Encyclopedia of Popular Music|The Guinness Who's Who of Country Music]]|editor=[[Colin Larkin (writer)|Colin Larkin]]|publisher=[[Guinness Publishing]]|date=1993|edition=First|isbn=0-85112-726-6|page=292}}</ref>

==Later career and death==
Eddie Noack quit performing after 1959 to concentrate on songwriting and to become involved in [[Music publisher (popular music)|music publishing]].<ref name="AMG"/> Noack was employed by Pappy Daily and [[Lefty Frizzell]] in publishing while he continued to write songs.<ref name="AMG"/>  His compositions were covered by many country singers, including [[Johnny Cash]] ("These Hands"),<ref name="AMG"/> [[George Jones]]<ref name="LarkinCountry"/> and [[Ernest Tubb]].

He made several comebacks as a performer but never reached a wide audience. In 1968, Noack recorded his cover of "Psycho" for K-Ark Records, which sold little and received negligible air play.<ref name="AMG"/>  He also continued recording into the 1970s, including an album of [[Jimmie Rodgers (country singer)|Jimmie Rodgers]] covers.<ref name="LarkinCountry"/> Among the labels he recorded for were [[All Star Records]], [[Mercury Records]], Tellet Country Records, and Wide World Records.<ref name="AMG"/>

In 1976, Noack moved to [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]], where he was employed as an executive with the [[Nashville Songwriters Association International|Nashville Songwriters Association]].<ref name="AMG"/> He recorded his final album that year, which was released by Look Records in the United Kingdom.<ref name="LarkinCountry"/> He backed up the album with a British tour.<ref name="LarkinCountry"/> His life took a drastic turn for the worse when both his wife in 1974, and his mother in 1977, took their own lives.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://singout.org/eddie-noacks-psycho/|title=Full Moon, Dark Heart: Eddie Noack's "Psycho" - Page 5 of 5|date=6 November 2017|website=Singout.org|access-date=8 August 2021}}</ref>

He was still an executive with the Nashville Songwriters Association, when the hard-drinking Noack died of a cerebral hemorrhage,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nashvillescene.com/music/eddie-noacks-twisted-country-death-song-trilogy-still-stalks-the-night/article_3a83d25a-e573-56de-b2cc-e3ae332430d3.html|title=Eddie Noack's twisted country death-song trilogy still stalks the night|first=Randy|last=Fox|website=Nashvillescene.com|access-date=8 August 2021}}</ref> at age 47, on February 5, 1978, in his home in Nashville.<ref name="AMG"/>  He is interred with his wife at Woodlawn Cemetery in Nashville.

According to [[Bob Dylan]] on the ''[[Theme Time Radio Hour Season One|Theme Time Radio Hour]]'' broadcast on January 24, 2007, "He wanted to be a journalist. But we have enough journalists, but not enough people who could sing and write like Eddie Noack. Eddie recorded the song called 'Psycho', written by Leon Payne, a song about a serial killer and quite understandably, it never got a lot of airplay, but has become quite a bit of a cult favorite, as is Eddie Noack himself..."<ref>{{cite web|title=Eddie Noack - BIO & DISCOGRAPHY |url=http://ttexshexes.blogspot.com/2010/12/re-blog-eddie-noack-bio-discography.html|website=Ttexshexes.blogspot.com|access-date=January 23, 2012|date=2010-12-16}}</ref>
